column1: #Text=## GeoGAN: Conditioning of three-dimensional generative adversarial networks for pore and reservoir-scale models
#Text=*Department of Earth Science and Engineering, Imperial College London*
#Text=This is the code repository accompanying the publication:
#Text= *Conditioning of three-dimensional generative adversarial networks for pore and reservoir-scale models*
#Text=The first one is trained on the Ketton limestone training image presented here.
#Text=If you decide to use this dataset for your own work, please consider citing the following works:
#Text=*Stochastic reconstruction of an oolitic limestone by generative adversarial networks*[[ArXiv](https://arxiv.org/abs/1712.02854)]
#Text=*Dynamic reservoir-condition microtomography of reactive transport in complex carbonates*[[Article](https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0016703717300789)]
#Text=Due to their size we provide the necessary files via a [Google Drive](https://drive.google.com/open?
#Text=The figure above shows two samples (b/c) obtained by a conditioning a generative adversarial network to three-orthogonal cross-sections of the Ketton training image(a).
#Text=Due to the stochastic nature of the optimization procedure the resulting images have distinctly different features away from the conditioning data.
#Text=We have trained a generative adversarial network on the Maules Creek alluvial aquifer training image.
#Text=The required model checkpoints are included in this repository.
#Text=If you choose to use the Maules Creek training image, please consider citing their originators at [trainingimages.org](www.trainingimages.org)
#Text=We have conditioned 1024 realizations of the Maules Creek alluvial aquifer model and present mean and standard deviation maps of the resulting ensemble.
#Text=The resulting images show that each realization honors the data at the well exactly and an ellipsoidal region of influence can be observed.
#Text=The conditioning tool is based on the following libraries:
#Text=We recommend using the [anaconda](https://anaconda.org/) distribution to install the required dependencies.
#Text=Currently the code has limited object oriented design and is usable as demonstrated by the accompanying jupyter notebooks.
#Text=We welcome contributions and suggestions for the improvement and development of the tool.
#Text=We recommend at least 16 GB of RAM and a modern CUDA capable NVIDIA graphics processor.
#Text=All experiments apart from network training have been performed on an NVIDIA 960M.
#Text=Training of the generative networks was performed on 8xNVIDIA K40 GPUs.
#Text=If you have any questions please feel free to contact us via [[email](lukas.mosser15@imperial.ac.uk)] or [[twitter](https://twitter.com/porestar)].
